results.title: Hungary’s Independent Press Takes Another Blow and Reporters Quit

results.title: Compensation for Embassy Bombing Victims Could Imperil Thaw With Sudan
results.abstract: A settlement to compensate victims of the 1998 attacks in Kenya and Tanzania would award more money to American embassy employees than the Africans.

results.title: Do We Need to Tell Our Son That His Dad Has Coronavirus?
results.abstract: He is 8 years old and very afraid of us getting sick.

results.title: Need Help With Your Estate Plan? Go With the Flow, Advisers Say
results.abstract: As older adults face mortality during the pandemic, lawyers and wealth advisers are using color-coded documents and flowcharts to help them understand estate planning.

multimedia.caption: Andrew D. Hendry found densely worded estate planning documents “really not useful to make a decision,” so his wealth adviser introduced him to a flowchart.
multimedia.copyright: Travis Dove for The New York Times

results.title: That ‘Home Office’ of Yours? It Needs an Upgrade
results.abstract: You may be working from home for a while. It’s time for something more professional than a corner of the dining table.

multimedia.caption: Working from home doesn’t necessarily require a lot of space. A closet-based office, like this one designed by Michael K. Chen in a 390-square-foot Manhattan studio, may be enough.

results.title: Suggestions, Distractions and Diaries. Our Staff Is an Open Book.
results.abstract: Worry is a drumbeat. Above it, though, there’s a melody: a craving for distraction and joy, for intimacy, for serendipity.

results.title: Where the Wild Things Play
results.abstract: The animal world is full of games. And tucked in among wrestling monkeys, belligerent birds and wily coyotes are lessons for us all.

results.title: ‘Almost Famous’: The Oral History of a Golden God’s Acid Trip
results.abstract: As the coming-of-age rock tale turns 20, the cast and crew remember how a star’s badly aimed jump and other near-misses became a standout scene.

results.title: Welcome to the Great Indoors: Museums Beckon in the Berkshires
results.abstract: At Mass MoCA and the Clark, there are timely new exhibitions, but our critic finds as much relevance in a still life by Manet, or an Ingres drawing.
org_facet: Clark, Sterling and Francine, Art Institute

multimedia.caption: In Blane De St. Croix’s ecologically minded show, a huge sheet of Styrofoam suggests melting permafrost and worn rock formations.

results.title: A Brooklyn Restaurant’s Answer to Cabin Fever: Summer Camp
results.abstract: Olmsted, like many of its New York City peers, is trying to make the most of a strange season by serving up fun and games along with the distancing.

multimedia.caption: Raised garden beds help keep tables well apart at Olmsted, one of many New York restaurants that are reinventing outdoor service this summer.

results.title: The Biases We Hold Against the Way People Speak
results.abstract: In “How You Say It,” Katherine Kinzler focuses on linguistic discrimination, how your accent can determine the way you are perceived.
des_facet: How You Say It: Why You Talk the Way You Do--And What It Says About You (Book)

results.title: Jason Rodriguez’s Vogue Family Values: Positivity, Trust, Love
results.abstract: The dancer and choreographer strives to empower a generation: “If you’re not expressing your most confident self, you’re not voguing.”

results.title: 3 Great Mysteries About Life on Mars
results.abstract: How habitable was early Mars? Why did it become less hospitable? And could there be life there now?

results.title: With Covid-19, a Seismic Quiet Like No Other
results.abstract: Coronavirus shutdowns led to “the longest and most coherent global seismic noise reduction in recorded history,” scientists report.

multimedia.caption: Scientists measured a drop in the global seismic din tied to human activity during pandemic lockdown. In New York’s Central Park, vibrations on Sunday nights during the peak lockdown period were 10 percent lower than previously measured.
multimedia.copyright: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

results.title: The Lightness of Being a Couch Potato May Work to Keep Us Fat
results.abstract: Sitting may confuse cellular sensors into thinking we are lighter than we are, prompting the body to put on weight.

results.title: Older Children Spread the Coronavirus Just as Much as Adults, Large Study Finds
results.abstract: The study of nearly 65,000 people in South Korea suggests that school reopenings will trigger more outbreaks.

multimedia.caption: Students, parents and teachers of Cheondong Elementary School in Daejeon, South Korea, got tested in early July after two students were found to be infected with the virus.

results.title: ‘Person. Woman. Man. Camera. TV.’ Didn’t Mean What Trump Hoped It Did
results.abstract: The president said on Fox News that he had to remember those words as part of a test that he said demonstrated his mental acuity. But the test, the Montreal Cognitive Assessment, is meant to detect signs of dementia, Alzheimer’s disease or other conditions.

multimedia.caption: President Trump has brought up his cognitive test repeatedly as a way of questioning the mental acuity of the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
President Trump has brought up his cognitive test repeatedly as a way of questioning the mental acuity of the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

results.title: Kimberly Guilfoyle’s Fund-Raising for Trump Draws Scrutiny
results.abstract: Ms. Guilfoyle has raised money from donors and has made inroads with some who have rejected calls from others. Yet Trump supporters inside and outside the campaign say the operation she’s built hasn’t lived up to expectations.
results.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Maggie Haberman

results.title: Trump vs. Biden: Who’s Winning the Money Race in Your ZIP Code?
results.abstract: We tracked donations to President Trump and Joe Biden over the last three months, and the numbers offer another sign of the nation’s political divisions. See where each candidate had more donors.
results.byline: By Rachel Shorey, K.K. Rebecca Lai and Thomas Kaplan
